newsitem.title: GERMANY: Friesian Isles fear being wiped off euro map.
newsitem.headline: Friesian Isles fear being wiped off euro map.

text.p: A group of small North Sea islands have added their own twist to the problem of who will or will not be included in European monetary union -- they say they have been wiped off the map featured on the new currency's notes.

The Friesian Council wrote to the German central bank in Frankfurt asking for the Friesian Isles, stretching from the Netherlands along the German coast to the Danish border, to be given their rightful place on the map of Europe.

The council, which represents the cultural interests of the Friesian people of the north German coastal region, said in its letter that the characteristic profile of the island chain was a "symbol of Friesian identity".

The Friesian Isles are in very good company, however, since the notes also omit the Spanish Balearic and Canary Isles, Portugal's island territories of Madeira and the Azores, and European Union candidate member Cyprus.
The designs of the banknotes are due to be refined this year. The single currency, the euro, is due to start in 1999 but the banknotes will not enter circulation until 2002.
